title: I Know You're Listening: Adaptive Voice for HRI
author: Paige Irène Tuttösí (Simon Fraser University), Angelica Lim (Simon Fraser University), Jean-Julien Aucouturier (FEMTO-ST Institute, CNRS), Mo Chen (Simon Fraser University), Lawrence Kim (Simon Fraser University), Tony Belpaeme (Ghent University), ...
relevance_why: The paper focuses on adaptive voice synthesis for social robots in language teaching, which could inform new approaches in audio generation and TTS systems related to educational applications.
background: The paper discusses using social robots to teach second languages through adaptive voice synthesis, tailored to both social context and the needs of language learners.
contribution: This thesis introduces a lightweight and expressive robot voice, adaptive vocal characteristics based on environmental noise, and a clear TTS system for L2 learners to improve language comprehension.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Existing approaches to TTS in robotics often lack expressivity and adaptability in real-time environments.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work improves by integrating emoji prompting for expressivity and adapting voice characteristics based on ambient conditions, enhancing listener engagement.

key_innovation: Implemented a fine-tuned TTS voice system that uses emoji-driven nuances to enhance expressivity, along with a contextual adaptation mechanism for varying environments.
real_world_impact: This research could significantly enhance the effectiveness of educational robots, making them more engaging and effective for language learners in diverse environments.
limitations: No explicit limitations are mentioned by the author.

new_terms.TTS: **Text-to-Speech** refers to technology that converts written text into spoken voice output.
new_terms.L2: **Second Language (L2)** refers to any language learned in addition to a person's native language.
